text: The next question is how do sentences integrate the higher order units of meaning.
speaker: Subject

text: The obvious first step peers towards the paragraph.
speaker: Subject

text: And here I want to quote Voloshinov one last time.
speaker: Subject

text: In certain crucial respects, paragraphs are analogues to exchanges in dialogue.
speaker: Subject

text: The paragraph is something like a vitiated dialogue worked in the body of a monologic utterance.
speaker: Subject

text: Behind the device of partitioning speech into units, which are termed paragraphs in their written form, lie orientation toward listener or reader in calculation of the latter's possible reactions.
speaker: Subject

text: The weaker this orientation and calculation are the less organized, as regards paragraphs, our speech will be.
speaker: Subject

text: This classic type of paragra- # th- this classic #
speaker: Subject

text: these classic types of paragraphs are question and answer, where the question's posed and answer given by the same author, supplementation, anticipation of possible objections, the type cited in Wellek and Warren,
speaker: Subject

text: exposition of seeming discrepancies or illogicalities in one's own argument, and so forth.
speaker: Subject

text: Very often we make our own speech or part of it the object of discussion.
speaker: Subject

text: In such a case, a shift occurs in the speaker's attention from the referent of his speech to the speech itself reflection over one's own words.
speaker: Subject

text: But even this shift in verbal intention is ((in #)) conditioned by the addressee's interest.
speaker: Subject

text: If we could imagine speech that absolutely ignored the addressee,
speaker: Subject

text: an impossible kind of speech of course, we would have a case of speech with organic partition reduced to the minimum.
speaker: Subject

text: Needless to say we are not thinking here of certain special types of partition shaped by the particular aims and purposes of specific ideological fields. For instance, the Strophic partition of speech and verse.
speaker: Subject

text: Or the purely logical partition of speech of t- # of the ((tight premised)) conclusion, thesis, antithesis and the like.
speaker: Subject

text: But we are of course thinking of exactly such things here.
speaker: Subject

text: And I want to point out that um the thing # that the partitioning of paragraphs # the idea of a paragraph as a vitiated dialogue is something that uh
speaker: Subject

text: is not radically different from the strategies you see in the work of David Bronwich's Essay ((Bones)), my poetry and others', and David Anton when he gave a talk over at ((Eightieth Langdon)) Street ((and)) actually described his own work in uh exactly of Voloshinov's terms as a vitiated dialogue.
